comments.body: did you mean to leave this here?
@vsiao oh uh I wasn't expecting this to be merged until your suggestion was applied :)  but yep this was intentional to gain the target attribute.
In what situation is it an array of strings?
In the case of a Select, it might be in  `<select multiple>`, I simply kept the definition that existed before and distributed it to form fields

ah sorry, I see it's not my pull request, typed too fast. I missed this one.

This definition looks correct to me.

Not sure about the use case of an array of strings, but that was the previous definition of the value prop:

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/fec422d2266ff5041bbc8082ca4c1d675f83efed/types/react/index.d.ts#L2449
I don't know how dtslint works here but I assume it's expecting you to copy the old react 15 `index.d.ts` to `react/v15/`.

That's actually not necessary, but if you do want to maintain multiple versions of react in parallel, you need to copy *all* of the old definitions to `v15` (incl. `tsconfig.json`, `tslint.json`, and `test`), not just `index.d.ts`.
`README.md` is ignored by types-publisher, so this might be a good time to move it into a comment instead.
Tests are now passing.
The stack is a string and not an array?
Yep! Here's a [pen](https://codepen.io/anon/pen/jLbJMj?editors=0010).
Should be `DetailedReactHTMLElement<InputHTMLAttributes<HTMLInputElement>, HTMLInputElement>`, I think.
You could also change the definition to take a union of string literal types to describe the set of valid arguments.

I would, but there are some none standard values that are useful in some browsers in some circumstances. I could try to list those too but I feel that the situation is that we then are trying to specify higher type safety than there is. All strings are allowed even though only a subset is usable which is similar to the situation with array indices, real numbers are allowed, just not useful. I also think many valid uses of it would error due to literal type widening as it is likely that you for example have an array of modifiers that you check.
@johnnyreilly since you merged it i hope you might know more :)

Yes, you are right! It is not useful now.
As I remember, I've added it because of typescript. There were some errors in console, if as attr is not in AnchorHTMLAttributes. So, I think, it is possible to get rid of it now.
Nice, thanks @artem-malko, i'll create a PR to remove it :D

Can it be `type: string | ComponentClass

| SFC

| Fragment` or I'm missing something? (same remark for code below)
Are you suggesting that I also add a new type alias named `Fragment` that is `symbol | number` and then use that instead as shorthand?
I'm a little confused by your suggestion; that's a value with the type `symbol | number`, not a type alias.

> that's a value [...] not a type alias

I know, you can then write `const Fragment: NEW_TYPE;`, NEW_TYPE being named something like `ReactFragment` since I guess naming it `Fragment` would clashname with the `const Fragment...`.

FYI a type `Fragment` exist in React Flow source code: https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/v16.1.0/packages/shared/ReactTypes.js#L18

Aha, I understand now. I would prefer keeping it explicit here to prevent confusion with [this type](https://github.com/uniqueiniquity/DefinitelyTyped/blob/4d07771b6c5ed5c3b75c7ee3e0d939557927403d/types/react/index.d.ts#L169).
Solid comment, haha
This change probably should be done to all instances of `crossOrigin` in the definitions

It should be possible to call `createContext()` to create one with `defaultValue` of `undefined`.

`function createContext<T>(): Context<T|undefined>` override? This is one of those that look like the antipattern warned against in the docs, but I think it's correct to use here, similar to a collection constructor.

Hmm. I'm confused here.  Calling `createContext()` (*i.e.,* no arguments) would require the `defaultValue` to be optional.  Otherwise you'd need to do an explicit `createContext(undefined)`.  Also, since `T` can be anything, I don't understand `T|undefined`.

FYI, I address this case of optional default values in [my article on the new Context API](https://medium.com/@mtiller/react-16-3-context-api-intypescript-45c9eeb7a384) (using the typings as they stand here, but wrapping them in one additional layer).  Also note that, in my opinion (see article), it isn't *just* about making the default value optional.  But again, I used these typings without issue.
16.3 released today and the docs seem to indicate @Kovensky is correct here â€” they use â€˜createContextâ€™ without args so it must be a correct usage. Iâ€™ll take a look at updating later today.
https://reactjs.org/docs/context.html

OK, rebased this post merge conflict.

Spent some time with this tonight and it looks like the behavior of the final API is that 
`createContext()`  gives you a context object where `_defaultValue` is undefined. 

`createContext('foo')` gives you a context object where `_defaultValue` is `foo`

Given that, I'm a bit confused as to the correct typing for `createContext()` with no params. I tried the overload @Kovensky mentioned but doing so types the resulting RenderProps function args with `{} or undefined`, which I don't think is correct. 

I suspect the overload closest to the API's usage would be

```
function createContext(): Context<any>
```

Which completely gives up type safety for RenderProps function but at least allows it to be used. `{} or undefined` doesn't allow you to still give, say, an anonymous object in the Provider's `value` field and still be able to retrieve it later in the RenderProps.

If anyone has any opinions on this they'd be welcome.

It resulting in `RenderProps` with `{}|undefined` was completely intended. You should call `createContext<MyContextType>()`, not just `createContext()`; similar to how you should call `new Set<valueType>()` instead of `new Set()`.

Although there is an argument for making it possible to `createContext<MyContextType>()` produce a function with render props of `MyContextType` instead of `MyContextType|undefined`; in this case, your provider's `value` type would have to be required and not include `undefined`.

But do _not_ make it produce a `Context<any>` without the user explicitly giving `<any>` as the template argument. That defeats the type safety that `--noImplicitAny` would gain you.
@Kovensky Yes, I agree. Thanks for the explanation. I've made it `T | undefined` for now.

Please correct me if I am wrong, but having the resulting `T` as `{}|undefined` means that I have to check for `undefined` in every Consumer use, right? I haven't actually tested that yet so I am probably wrong :)

```tsx
const context = createContext<MyContextType>()

<Provider value={myValue}>
  <Consumer>{(value: MyContextType | undefined ) => /* adding type here just to show an issue */ }</Consumer>
</Provider>
```

If this is the case, then it's definitely a bad way to go imo. Sadly, my TypeScript knowledge is limited and I am not sure about better way here.

Yup, I'm just saying that we shouldn't want to correct that behavior, because you can always use `Consumer` not paired with a `Provider` so the value of `T` should not change even if you later pass in the value as a prop to `Provider`. 

I.e. if you create the context with the default value, you are *always* guaranteed to have a defined value wherever you use `Consumer` (even not as a descendant of `Provider`), but once you create the context without a default value, you are not guaranteed that defined value unless you wrap the `Consumer` inside a `Provider`, which wouldn't be able to be statically analyzed before runtime.

I'm agreeing with you that it's unfortunate that we'll always have to check for undefined, but I think that should be the way the interface is structured due to the lack of compile-time guarantees of the consumer value

Well, in your first example you had the comment there `/* value here will be defined, even though it's typed as optional */` and that was what's confused me the most. As you have said now, you will have to check for `undefined` either way. I understand now. I see a bit of problem arising here. Developers are generally lazy and we might end up with pattern like this. ```tsx interface MyContextType { myValue: string } const Context = createContext() {value => {
{value!.myValue.toUpperCase()}
// <-- notice the "!" mark there ``` That might be a good source of runtime errors (_and blaming TypeScript/React for it_) in case someone really forgets to add the Provider. It's true that if anyone is using `!` it's for own risk, but there are people that might just copy&paste and then be surprised. --- What about this approach? Would this work the same way? I am not sure if it's a correct syntax, but you get the gist. This would at least allow to override this `undefined` type in case someone knows what they are doing. ```ts function createContext(): Context; ```

@ferdaber I'm trying to use the TypeScript 2.8 features you mentioned in this definition, but it looks like that's not possible yet? 

I've updated the headers to `// TypeScript Version: 2.8` but that results in a linting error.

According to this comment, we can only use TypeScript up to 2.7 right now, so I may not be able to use the definition you specify.

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/24586#issuecomment-376911352
ah, that's too bad, we'll keep it in the backburner then
Clarifying question: with this change would the expectation be that any new component created, that uses snapshots, would need to specify the snapshot type in the class declaration?
That's the idea; otherwise this would have had to be typed as `any`.

Is it actually a component, or just a callback?

Though arguably any function that returns `ReactNode` is a component if it reads its parameters in a compatible way.

Would it be possible to use a secret `unique symbol` to brand this interface and make it only constructible via `createRef`? Or would any `unique symbol`s we declare be visible to user code, even if it doesn't exist?

Interestingly though, the source really does just construct a plain object and return it (despite the fact that it's sealed in `DEV` mode), so a user passing in a plain object into `ref` will also find that it works:

https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/master/packages/react/src/ReactCreateRef.js

That's interesting ðŸ¤” 

I thought it'd brand the returned object, similar to the context/provider pair, but I guess they get away with not branding it since it's not something you give as the first argument to `createElement` ðŸ˜„
My guess is it will be more annoying than useful to treat `current` as nullable (even though it technically is).
This is the same behavior as the current argument to ref callbacks; you also can brute force your way through it by using a `!`.

The definite assignment is a different problem. You are checking if `elem` is `null` or not with `elem &&`, and so when you do the assignment, `null` has already been eliminated from `elem`'s domain. The definite assignment lets you avoid the `undefined` state, but `null` is a normal part of the API; the type of the `elem` _parameter_ is `HTMLInputElement | null`.
What it allows you to do is treat `this.elem` as non-null everywhere _else, i.e. to avoid having to use `this.elem!` everywhere.
That behavior is only correct if your subtree is always mounted. If your subtree is mounted conditionally, you now have a hidden `null` reference. The `| null` here is _correct behavior_.

Yes, and if you happen to know itâ€™s always mounted this is exactly the use case for the definite assignment assertion feature. Itâ€™s a small compromise in type safety but very convenient for situations where you know better than the compiler. This is why the feature exists. By forcing `current` to be `| null` we lose the option to exercise such discretion, so itâ€™s a step backwards. Again, you can always opt in to perfect type safety by declaring the type parameter of the `RefObject` to be `| null`, but you _cannot opt out_ if the decision is made for you.

No, this is _not_ the use case for definite assignment assertion. The definite assignment is for avoiding the presence of `undefined` _specifically_.

Do not confuse `null` with `undefined`. You are specifically avoiding `null` by checking for it and never assigning `null` to your local ref, which is actually a potential memory leak. There's a reason why React will call your `ref` callback with `null`.
Hm, you may be right, but how is it a potential memory leak? Doesn't React release instances once unmounted, thereby releasing their fields?

```ts function cloneElement( element: SFCElement

, props?: (Pick | P) & Attributes, ...children: ReactNode[] ): SFCElement

``` Similarly for the other overloads. This is similar to the `setState` trick to avoid accepting `undefined` unless `undefined` is actually an acceptable value for the prop. --- EDIT: I actually tried this locally, and it seems that something breaks because TypeScript tries to use the wrong overload (`P extends React.HTMLAttributes`???), so probably better to keep `Partial` for now. Speaking of which, should the other overloads also be updated?
I also wonder if there's a way to get a better type for `...children`, but that's probably for another PR.
What is "P extends React.HTMLAttributes<T>"? Could you please provide more details?
That's one of the generic parameters from another of the `cloneElement` overloads. That's the overload typescript tried to use when I tried to make this one work with `Pick`.
We should really try to make this work with Pick. Partial is evil.
I'd say it's better to get this in with `Partial` first, as it's still better than requiring an `as` cast. Figuring out how to get `Pick` working would be a future task... ðŸ˜¢
